   Imaging: [**1-8**] CXR wet-read: vascular redistribution, interstitial

   atelectasis. new left basilar opacity adjacent to cardiac silhouette
   may reflect infection.
   Microbiology: [**1-6**] Cdiff negative, fecal cx pending
   Assessment and Plan
 CHEST PAIN
   73 year-old gentleman with history of ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF (EF
   30%), moderate to severe AS (valve area 0.9), CAD with BMS to RCA on
   [**2150-11-27**], recent NSTEMI on [**2150-12-7**], and B-cell lymphoma with recent
   chemotherapy with vincritine and rituximab c/b tumor-lysis syndrome.
   Originally presented to oncology service on [**2150-12-6**] with LLQ pain
   that in past has been consistent with worsening of his lymphoma.
   #. Chest pain:
   Patient has had four ~10 minute episodes of crushing substernal chest
   pain. Associated EKG changes. Cardiology has been made aware of the
   patient's ongoing chest pain. He has received a complete cycle of 3
   sets of cardiac biomarkers any a 24 hour period without evidence of
   NSTEMI. Though chest pain is most likely consistent with prior
   ischemia, must also consider additional etiologies of chest pain. Given
   cough with sputum and new infiltrate on CXR, should keep pneumonia on
   our minds as another etiology of chest pain or as an incidental
   finding.
   - Two additional sets of cardiac enzymes
   - Repeat EKG if additional CP episodes
   - Follow-up additional set of cardiac biomarkers at midnight and 0600
   - Consider anticoagulation with heparin if additional chest apin
   - Continue aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, metoprolol as tolerated
   - Cardiology consult to assist in ongoing managment in AM or sooner if
   repeat episodes of CP overnight
   - Trend fever curve and monitor of leukocytosis
   #. Follicular lymphoma:
   Patient is now day two of oncovine, bendamustine, and decadron
   administered. Originally scheduled to receive rituximab on [**2151-1-9**].
   Last time he had this regimen he developed tumor lysis syndrome. In
   setting of missed dialysis, potassium is elevated. Phosphate up
   slightly this evening to 4.8 from 4.3 earlier. Uric acid up to 8.7 from
   7.7. LDH is stable.
   - Appreciate oncology input regarding further chemotherapy in setting
   of transfer to ICU
   - Monitor K, phos, LDH, uric acid Q6H
   - Decadron 20 mg IV x 5 days started [**1-7**]
   - Allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD
   - Tomorrow: rituximab scheduled currently, if we decide to proceed, it
   must be give *after* dialysis
   - Acetaminophen and diphenhydramine prior to rituximab
   #. Hyperkalemia:
   Patient's K has been climbing today in setting of missed dialysis due
   to holiday in addition to tumor lysis. EKGs from earlier in day are
   concerning for more prominent T waves as well as a widened QRS to ~150
   in background of baseline QRS ~120. Calcium gluconate was not given at
   that time.
   - Checking Q6H lytes
   - Repeat EKG if potassium elevated above 6.4
   - Pending EKG, will decide on calcium gluconate, though should likely
   give additional kaexylate and D50 + insulin if K still elevated
   # Hyperuricemia:  Uric acid climbing through the day yesterday in
   setting of tumor lysis and renal failure.
   - consider rasburicase.
   #. Hypotension:
   Patient is having period asymptomatic BP dropping to 70s systolic.
   Possible that this is not a true [**Location (un) **] given excellent mental status.
   Will have to attempt to corraborate with manual arm pressures and as a
   last resort will need to place arterial line to obtain a true pressure.
   #. ESRD:
   HD MWF at [**Location (un) 4465**] [**Location (un) 590**] as an outpatient. Received HD [**1-6**]. Calcium
   acetate had been stopped and phos repleted given very low phosphate
   earlier in course, though phos has climbed to 4.8 prior to transfer to
   the ICU. No urgent indication for HD currently, though volume
   management is becoming problem[**Name (NI) 595**].
   - Dialysis tomorrow
   - Continue renal diet
   - Trend phos/K
   #. Diabetes:
   - QID FS
   - ISS if needed
   #. CHF:
   Currently appears volume up by CXR and pulm exam.
   - Continue lisinopril, metoprolol as tolerated
   - Dialysis tomorrow
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Renal diet
   Glycemic Control: HISS
   Lines:  PIVs, port-a-cath, dialysis catheter
   Prophylaxis:
   -DVT ppx with heparin subcutaneous
   -Bowel regimen with docusate and senna
   Communication:  [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11759**], wife, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12353**]
   Code status: FULL, family notes that goals of care should not be
   directly addressed with patient has he has indicated in past that he
   would not want to know his prognosis as it may destroy his hopes of
   recovery. Family requests Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6521**] to be involved in any goals of
   care discussion.
   Disposition: ICU for now

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF, moderate to severe AS, CAD, and B-cell lymphoma. He presented to the ICU with chest pain, which has been ongoing for four episodes, each lasting around 10 minutes. The chest pain is associated with EKG changes, and cardiac biomarkers have been monitored. 

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated potassium levels (6.5 mg/dL)
* Worsening uric acid levels (8.7 mg/dL)
* Elevated LDH levels (1875 IU/L)
* Phosphate levels are slightly elevated (4.8 mg/dL)
* Calcium levels are normal (7.1 mg/dL)
* Magnesium levels are normal (2.2 mg/dL)
* Phosphate levels are slightly elevated (5.2 mg/dL)

Imaging studies reveal:

* CXR shows vascular redistribution, interstitial prominence, and early interstitial edema, as well as persistent retrocardiac atelectasis and new left basilar opacity adjacent to the cardiac silhouette, which may indicate infection.

The patient is being treated for:

* Chest pain: Two additional sets of cardiac enzymes, repeat EKG, and follow-up cardiac biomarkers at midnight and 0600. Anticoagulation with heparin is being considered, and cardiology consultation is planned.
* Follicular lymphoma: The patient is receiving oncovine, bendamustine, and decadron, and rituximab is scheduled for tomorrow, pending dialysis.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels are being monitored, and repeat EKG will be done if potassium levels remain elevated above 6.4.
* Hyperuricemia: The patient's uric acid levels are being monitored, and rasburicase is being considered.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is dropping to the 70s systolic, and manual arm pressures are being attempted to confirm the reading.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Tumor lysis syndrome
* Cardiac ischemia or infarction
* Pneumonia
* Infection
* Renal failure
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Hypotension

The patient's code status is FULL, and his family has requested that Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6521**] be involved in any goals of care discussions. The patient is currently being treated in the ICU, and his disposition is uncertain at this time.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction of 30%, moderate to severe aortic stenosis, and coronary artery disease with a history of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). He is currently undergoing chemotherapy for follicular lymphoma and has a history of tumor lysis syndrome.

The patient presented to the ICU with chest pain, which has been ongoing since admission. The pain has been described as "crushing" and has been associated with electrocardiogram (EKG) changes. Cardiology has been consulted, and the patient has received a complete cycle of cardiac biomarkers without evidence of NSTEMI.

The patient's laboratory results show worsening uric acid levels, likely due to tumor lysis syndrome. His potassium levels are also elevated, which may be related to missed dialysis and tumor lysis syndrome. His phosphate levels are slightly elevated, and his calcium levels are normal.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a temperature of 36.2°C (97.2°F), a heart rate of 73 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 74/45 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 10 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 95% on nasal cannula oxygen. His peripheral vascular examination is incomplete due to the patient's inability to move.

The patient's imaging studies show vascular redistribution, interstitial prominence, and retrocardiac atelectasis on chest X-ray (CXR). The CXR also shows a new left basilar opacity adjacent to the cardiac silhouette, which may reflect infection.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's chest pain and EKG changes may be related to cardiac ischemia or infarction. His history of NSTEMI and CHF also increases his risk of cardiac complications.
2. Infection: The patient's CXR shows evidence of pneumonia, which may be contributing to his chest pain and respiratory symptoms.
3. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's laboratory results show worsening uric acid levels, which may be related to tumor lysis syndrome. This condition can lead to acute kidney injury, cardiac arrhythmias, and other complications.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels are elevated, which may be related to missed dialysis and tumor lysis syndrome. This condition can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
5. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which may be related to volume depletion or cardiac compromise. This condition can lead to organ hypoperfusion and other complications.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current laboratory results, I recommend the following plan:

1. Continue cardiac biomarkers to monitor for cardiac complications.
2. Repeat EKG and chest X-ray to monitor for signs of cardiac ischemia or infarction.
3. Administer anticoagulation with heparin to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
4. Continue dialysis to manage the patient's electrolyte imbalances and volume status.
5. Monitor the patient's potassium levels closely and administer calcium gluconate as needed to prevent cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Consider rasburicase to manage the patient's hyperuricemia and reduce the risk of tumor lysis syndrome.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if necessary.
8. Continue the patient's chemotherapy regimen, but consider modifying the regimen based on the patient's laboratory results and clinical status.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications. Close monitoring and management of his electrolyte imbalances, cardiac status, and respiratory function are critical to preventing further complications and improving his outcome.

The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), chronic systolic heart failure (CHF), moderate to severe aortic stenosis, and coronary artery disease. He was admitted to the ICU with chest pain and has been experiencing recurrent episodes of chest pain. He is currently receiving chemotherapy for follicular lymphoma and has a Port-a-cath and dialysis catheter in place.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 73 bpm, and blood pressure of 74/45 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 10 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 95%. He has a slight increase in his uric acid levels and is at risk for tumor lysis syndrome.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Hyperkalemia: His potassium levels are elevated, and he is at risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Hyperuricemia: His uric acid levels are elevated, and he is at risk for gout and kidney damage.
3. Hypotension: His blood pressure is dropping to the 70s systolic, which may be due to fluid overload or a true hypotensive episode.
4. ESRD: He has end-stage renal disease and is receiving dialysis three times a week.
5. CHF: He has chronic systolic heart failure and is at risk for further cardiac decompensation.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias due to hyperkalemia
2. Gout and kidney damage due to hyperuricemia
3. Further cardiac decompensation due to CHF
4. Tumor lysis syndrome due to chemotherapy
5. Infection due to the patient's immunocompromised state

The patient's code status is "full," and his family has requested that Dr. [Last Name] be involved in any goals of care discussions.

   73 year-old gentleman with history of ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF (EF

   pain. Associated EKG changes. Cardiology has been made aware of the
   patient's ongoing chest pain. He has received a complete cycle of 3
   sets of cardiac biomarkers any a 24 hour period without evidence of
   NSTEMI. Though chest pain is most likely consistent with prior
   ischemia, must also consider additional etiologies of chest pain. Given
   cough with sputum and new infiltrate on CXR, should keep pneumonia on
   our minds as another etiology of chest pain or as an incidental
   finding.

   - Follow-up additional set of cardiac biomarkers at midnight and 0600
   - Consider anticoagulation with heparin if additional chest apin
   - Continue aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, metoprolol as tolerated
   - Cardiology consult to assist in ongoing managment in AM or sooner if
   repeat episodes of CP overnight
   - Trend fever curve and monitor of leukocytosis
   #. Follicular lymphoma:
   Patient is now day two of oncovine, bendamustine, and decadron
   administered. Originally scheduled to receive rituximab on [**2151-1-9**].

   setting of missed dialysis, potassium is elevated. Phosphate up

   in background of baseline QRS ~120. Calcium gluconate was not given at

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a history of ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF, moderate to severe AS, CAD, and B-cell lymphoma. He was recently admitted to the ICU with chest pain, which has been attributed to prior ischemia, but other etiologies such as pneumonia and tumor lysis syndrome are also being considered. He has received a complete cycle of 3 sets of cardiac biomarkers without evidence of NSTEMI. The patient is also experiencing hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, and hypotension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Pneumonia could lead to sepsis, which could exacerbate cardiac conditions.
	* Tumor lysis syndrome could cause cardiac arrhythmias and hypotension.
	* Hyperkalemia could lead to cardiac arrest.
2. Renal Complications:
	* Hyperuricemia could lead to acute kidney injury.
	* Hyperkalemia could lead to acute kidney injury.
	* Volume management is becoming a problem, and dialysis is necessary to manage fluid overload.
3. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia could lead to respiratory failure.
	* Aspiration pneumonia could occur due to altered mental status.
4. Neurological Complications:
	* Tumor lysis syndrome could cause neurological symptoms such as seizures and altered mental status.
	* Hyperkalemia could lead to neurological symptoms such as muscle weakness and paralysis.
5. Infection:
	* Pneumonia is a possibility, and the patient's cough and sputum production suggest this.
	* The patient's lymphoma and recent chemotherapy increase the risk of infection.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his cardiac, renal, and respiratory status. He also requires aggressive management of his hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, and hypotension. Additionally, the patient's oncology and cardiology teams should be consulted to develop a comprehensive plan for his care.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 73-year-old male with Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL), End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD), and Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) who recently had a Non-ST Segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI). He is currently receiving chemotherapy and is experiencing tumor lysis syndrome. He was transferred to the ICU due to chest pain and medication-induced hypotension.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.2°C (97.2°F)
* Heart rate: 77 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 73/43 mmHg (46/32 mmHg - 96/48 mmHg mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 97%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Well-nourished appearance
* No acute distress
* No signs of anxiety or diaphoresis
* Normocephalic head
* Normal pupillary response
* Soft, non-tender abdomen
* Warm skin with no rash or jaundice
* Attentive and follows simple commands

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.2 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 3.4 K/uL
* Platelet count: 65 K/uL
* Creatinine: 6.5 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.18 ng/mL
* Glucose: 253 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 12.7/29.9/1.1, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 20/4/0.18, ALT/AST: 17/34, Alk Phos/T Bili: 69/0.2

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's conditions include:

* Cardiac complications due to underlying AoStenosis and recent NSTEMI
* Respiratory complications due to fluid overload and potential respiratory failure
* Renal complications due to ESRD and potential acute kidney injury
* Hematological complications due to tumor lysis syndrome and potential bleeding
* Infection complications due to indwelling lines and catheters
* Gastrointestinal complications due to tumor lysis syndrome and potential bleeding
* Neurological complications due to potential bleeding and hypotension

Based on the patient's current condition and laboratory results, the plan includes:

* Monitoring for chest pain and cardiac enzymes
* Managing hypotension and fluid overload
* Continuing chemotherapy and tumor lysis syndrome management
* Hemodialysis for ESRD
* Close monitoring of laboratory results and potential complications
* Potential transfer to the floor after hemodialysis, depending on blood pressure.

Chief Complaint: Chest pain
   24 Hour Events:
   --Patient had an episode of chest pain overnight, which was consistent
   with previous episodes of angina.  Patient was treated with dilaudid
   and ativan; nitro not given due to severe AS.  Most likely real chest
   pain, given cardiac history.  We thought that chest pain might be
   related to hypotension (poor cardiac perfusino) so we gave back a
   little bit of fluid.  Cardiology was curbsided, who said that patient
   is not a candidate for cath given his extensive disease.  Patient
   eventually fell asleep and the rest of the night was uneventful.
   --Patient received dialysis yesterday AM and 1 liter was removed
   --Patient's family came by and are aware of situation
   --Patient continues to be hypotensive with SBPs in the 60s.

   Assessment and Plan
 CHEST PAIN
   73 year-old gentleman with history of ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF (EF
   30%), moderate to severe AS (valve area 0.9), CAD with BMS to RCA on
   [**2150-11-27**], recent NSTEMI on [**2150-12-7**], and B-cell lymphoma with recent
   chemotherapy with vincritine and rituximab c/b tumor-lysis syndrome.
   Transferred from OMED for frequent episodes of chest pain.
   #. Chest pain:   One episode of chest pain overnight.  Enzymes are
   flat, but EKG did show some increased ST depressions in lead 1.
   Cardiology was curbsided who confirmed that patient is not a good
   candidate for stenting due to his extensive disease.  Patient also has
   bad cough; an element of pleuritis might be involved in chest pain as
   well.
   - f/u morning cardiac enzymes.
   - Repeat EKG if additional CP episodes
   - Continue aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, metoprolol as tolerated.
   - Cardiology consult to assist in ongoing managment
   - Trend fever curve and monitor of leukocytosis
   #. Follicular lymphoma:
   Patient is now day three of oncovine, bendamustine, and decadron
   administered. Originally scheduled to receive rituximab on [**2151-1-9**],
   but most likely will not get it until [**1-10**].  Last time he had this
   regimen he developed tumor lysis syndrome.  Phosphate up slightly this
   evening to 4.8 from 4.3 earlier. Uric acid up to 8.7 from 7.7. LDH is
   stable.
   - Appreciate oncology input regarding further chemotherapy in setting
   of transfer to ICU.  Need to clarify with them whether to give
   Rituximab.
   - Monitor K, phos, LDH, uric acid Q8H
   - Decadron 20 mg IV x 5 days started [**1-7**]
   - Allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD
   - Acetaminophen and diphenhydramine prior to rituximab
   #. Hyperkalemia:
   Potassium improved overnight after kayexalate and large BM.
   - Checking Q6H lytes
   - Repeat EKG if potassium trending up.
   - If EKG changes, give calcium gluconate, consider D50 w/ regular
   insulin.  Then give kayexalate.
   # Hyperuricemia:  Uric acid climbing through the day yesterday in
   setting of tumor lysis and renal failure.
   - would usually consider rasburicase, but given ESRD, unlikely to have
   a clinical effect.  Will simply monitor for now and continue
   allopurinol.
   #. Hypotension:
   Patient is having period asymptomatic BP dropping to 70s systolic.
   Possible that this is not a true [**Location (un) **] given excellent mental status
   and that we are getting BPs from thigh cuff.  This morning, dialysis
   nurse says left leg better, unclear why right arm cannot be used and
   patient does not know.
   - If he becomes at all mentally altered, place A-line.
   #. ESRD:
   HD MWF at [**Location (un) 4465**] [**Location (un) 590**] as an outpatient. Received HD [**1-6**]. Calcium
   acetate had been stopped and phos repleted given very low phosphate
   earlier in course, though phos has climbed to 4.8 prior to transfer to
   the ICU. Will be dialyzed today.
   - Continue renal diet
   - Trend phos/K
   #. Diabetes:
   - QID FS
   - ISS if needed
   #. CHF:
   Currently appears volume up by CXR and pulm exam.
   - Continue lisinopril, metoprolol when blood pressure tolerates.
   - Should improve with dialysis.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Indwelling Port (PortaCath) - [**2151-1-8**] 07:30 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2151-1-8**] 07:30 PM

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF, moderate to severe AS, CAD, and B-cell lymphoma. The patient was transferred to the ICU due to frequent episodes of chest pain.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Chest pain: One episode overnight, consistent with previous episodes of angina. Cardiology was consulted, and the patient is not a candidate for stenting due to extensive disease.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is in the 60s, with a possible element of pleuritis contributing to the chest pain.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels improved overnight after kayexalate and a large bowel movement. Monitoring is ongoing.
* Hyperuricemia: The patient's uric acid levels are climbing due to tumor lysis syndrome and renal failure.
* ESRD: The patient is undergoing hemodialysis three times a week as an outpatient and received dialysis yesterday.
* Diabetes: The patient's blood sugar levels are being monitored and controlled with insulin.
* CHF: The patient appears volume overloaded based on CXR and pulmonary exam.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's B-cell lymphoma treatment may lead to tumor lysis syndrome, which can cause hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of sCHF, AS, and CAD increases the risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and myocardial infarction.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient's chronic lung disease and pleuritis may lead to respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
4. Renal complications: The patient's ESRD and hyperuricemia may lead to further kidney damage or acute kidney injury.
5. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and central venous catheters increase the risk of infection, such as sepsis, bacteremia, or catheter-related bloodstream infection.
6. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension and potential pleuritis may lead to further hemodynamic instability, requiring close monitoring and intervention.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following plan should be considered:

1. Continue cardiac monitoring and management, including EKGs and cardiac enzymes.
2. Monitor the patient's potassium, phosphorus, and uric acid levels closely and adjust treatment as needed.
3. Continue dialysis and adjust the patient's fluid management to prevent volume overload.
4. Monitor the patient's blood sugar levels and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
5. Consider prophylactic antibiotics and antifungal therapy to prevent infection.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider mechanical ventilation if necessary.
7. Consider consulting with cardiothoracic surgery for further management of the patient's cardiac condition.
8. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider placing an arterial line if necessary.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of chest pain. He has a history of cardiac disease and has been experiencing episodes of angina. Overnight, he had another episode of chest pain, which was treated with dilaudid and ativan. His cardiac history and severe aortic stenosis (AS) make it likely that the chest pain is real. The patient continues to be hypotensive with systolic blood pressures in the 60s. He received dialysis yesterday morning and had 1 liter removed. His family is aware of his situation.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: Given the patient's cardiac history and ongoing hypotension, there is a risk of further cardiac compromise, including cardiac arrest or arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's hypotension may lead to decreased cardiac output, which could compromise his respiratory function and increase the risk of respiratory failure.
3. Infection: The patient's indwelling lines and catheters increase his risk of developing infections, such as catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSIs) or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
4. Fluid imbalance: The patient's ongoing fluid losses and hypotension may lead to further fluid imbalances, including hypovolemia or fluid overload.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's poor nutritional status and ongoing fluid losses may lead to malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's ongoing hypotension and fluid losses may lead to further hemodynamic instability, including decreased cardiac output and blood pressure.
7. Renal complications: The patient's ongoing hypotension and fluid losses may lead to further renal compromise, including acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD).
8. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's ongoing fluid losses and electrolyte imbalances may lead to further electrolyte imbalances, including hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, or hyperphosphatemia.

These potential complications highlight the need for continued close monitoring and management of the patient's cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal functions, as well as his fluid and electrolyte balance.

 CHEST PAIN
   73 year-old gentleman with history of ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF (EF
   30%), moderate to severe AS (valve area 0.9), CAD with BMS to RCA on
   [**2150-11-27**], recent NSTEMI on [**2150-12-7**], and B-cell lymphoma with recent
   chemotherapy with vincritine and rituximab complicated by tumor-lysis
   syndrome.  Patient transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for recurrent episodes of chest
   pain.
   #. Chest pain:   One episode of chest pain overnight, concerning for
   ischemia.  Very difficult to treat patient, as we
re loathe to give
   nitrates in light of AS, and cardiogy states that he is not a good
   candidate for stenting/CABG.  As such, we
ve just been treating the
   patient symptomatically, doing EKGs, and cycling enzymes.  However,
   with new onset cough, some chest pain may be related to pleuritis, but
   doubt this is responsible for acute attacks.
   - Cardiology consult for further management
   - Dilaudid, ativan, other acceptable pain management for now
   - 02 to maintain sats and for comfort
   - Would consider BB, though BP is quite low
   - Repeat EKG if additional CP episodes
   - Continue aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin
   - Obtain repeat CXR to check for brewing PNA
   #. Hypotension:  Patient with baseline systolic blood pressures in the
   60s-70s.  Unclear if this is an accurate [**Location (un) **], as we
ve been putting
   the cuff on patient
s thigh (can
t get readings on either arm).
   However, even during episodes of hypotension, patient mentates well and
   has no signs/symptoms of decreased perfusion.  We need a more accurate
   measurement.
   - Discuss with patient, cardiology, other providers about the utility
   of placing A-line.
   #. Follicular lymphoma:
   Patient is in middle of cycle of oncovine, bendamustine, and decadron
   administered. Originally scheduled to receive rituximab on [**2151-1-9**],
   but held off due to episode of chest pain on the floor.  Moreover, the
   last time Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 6471**] received this regimen he had severe tumor lysis
   syndrome.  As such, we
re trending tumor lysis labs.  Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 6471**] was
   set to continue the chemotherapy today, but we
ll have to see how
   things play out with his chest pain
   - Appreciate oncology input regarding further chemotherapy in setting
   of transfer to ICU.  Need to clarify with them whether to give
   Rituximab.
   - Monitor K, phos, LDH, uric acid Q12 (or Q8 if labs continue to be
   unconcerning)
   - Decadron 20 mg IV x 5 days started [**1-7**]
   - Allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD
   - Acetaminophen and diphenhydramine prior to rituximab
   #. Hypokalemia:  In setting of dialysis and kayexelate.  Continue to
   replete as needed.
   #. ESRD:  On dialysis MWF.  Last dialysis was on [**1-8**]; next scheduled
   for [**1-11**], but we
ll need to confirm with renal.
   #. Diabetes:
   - QID FS
   - ISS if needed
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  Renal diet
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Indwelling Port (PortaCath) - [**2151-1-8**] 07:30 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2151-1-8**] 07:30 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Subcu heparin
   Stress ulcer: Ranitidine 150mg PO QD
   Code status: To be discussed with family and primary oncologist as soon
   as possible.
   Disposition:  ICU for now.

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, chronic systolic heart failure (EF 30%), moderate to severe aortic stenosis (AS), coronary artery disease (CAD), and B-cell lymphoma. He was recently diagnosed with non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and has been experiencing recurrent episodes of chest pain. He was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management.

The patient had an episode of chest pain overnight, which was treated with dilaudid and ativan. His cardiac history and recent NSTEMI make it likely that the chest pain is related to ischemia. However, due to his severe AS, he is not a candidate for stenting or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He is being treated symptomatically with EKGs and cycling enzymes.

The patient is also experiencing hypotension, with systolic blood pressures in the 60s-70s. This is unclear, as the cuff is being placed on his thigh due to difficulty getting readings on either arm. He is being monitored closely, and the utility of placing an arterial line is being discussed.

The patient is also receiving chemotherapy for his lymphoma, which was previously held due to his episode of chest pain. His oncologist is being consulted for further management, and his tumor lysis labs are being monitored.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD, NSTEMI, and severe AS make him at risk for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's chronic heart failure and recent NSTEMI make him at risk for respiratory complications, including pneumonia, pleural effusion, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Infectious complications: The patient's immunocompromised state due to his chemotherapy and history of B-cell lymphoma make him at risk for infectious complications, including sepsis, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections.
4. Metabolic complications: The patient's history of diabetes and chronic kidney disease make him at risk for metabolic complications, including hyperglycemia, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia.
5. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's history of chemotherapy and recent NSTEMI make him at risk for hemorrhagic complications, including bleeding diathesis and gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of chemotherapy and recent NSTEMI make him at risk for neurological complications, including seizures, stroke, and encephalopathy.

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old male with severe CAD, AoS, CHF, recent NSTEMI, B-cell lymphoma, and ESRD on HD. He is experiencing persistent chest pain (CP) and hypotension, which is exacerbated by inadequate supply-demand ratio, volume overload, and hypotension. Despite receiving dilaudid and ativan, his pain remains uncontrolled. He is not a cath candidate and has limited interventional or medical options.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's underlying CAD, AoS, and CHF increase the risk of cardiac complications, including acute coronary syndrome, cardiac arrest, or worsening heart failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's chronic respiratory disease and recent NSTEMI increase the risk of respiratory complications, including pneumonia, respiratory failure, or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Infectious complications: The patient's immunosuppressed state due to lymphoma and chronic kidney disease increase the risk of infections, including sepsis, urinary tract infections, or pneumonia.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastrointestinal upset and recent chemotherapy increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, including nausea, vomiting, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's chronic kidney disease and recent chemotherapy increase the risk of neurological complications, including seizures, stroke, or cognitive impairment.
6. Hematological complications: The patient's lymphoma and chronic kidney disease increase the risk of hematological complications, including anemia, bleeding, or blood clotting disorders.
7. Endocrine complications: The patient's chronic kidney disease and recent chemotherapy increase the risk of endocrine complications, including hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or thyroid dysfunction.
8. Nutritional complications: The patient's chronic kidney disease and recent chemotherapy increase the risk of nutritional complications, including malnutrition, dehydration, or electrolyte imbalances.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, lab results, and overall clinical status to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF, moderate to severe AS, CAD, B-cell lymphoma, and recent chemotherapy with vincritine and rituximab complicated by tumor-lysis syndrome. The patient was transferred to the ICU for recurrent episodes of chest pain.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 36.5°C, Tcurrent 36.3°C, HR 101 bpm, BP 49/31 mmHg, RR 17 insp/min, SpO2 90%
* Respiratory support: O2 delivery device nasal cannula 6L, ABG pH 7.28
* Physical examination: Comfortable, no acute distress; crackles in the right lung base to mid-lung, RRR, normal S1 and S2, +BS, soft, non-tender, non-distended abdomen, trace edema bilaterally, +peripheral pulses
* Labs: WBC 3.4 K/uL, Hct 27.7%, Plt 65, Cr 6.5 mg/dL, Trop-T 0.18 ng/mL, Glucose 151 mg/dL
* CXR: Worsening opacity involving the retrocardiac portion of the left lower lobe and part of the adjacent lingula, which could be due to evolving pneumonia in the appropriate clinical setting

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Chest pain: Consistent with ischemia, but difficult to treat due to AS and cardiologist's recommendation against stenting/CABG.
2. Hypotension: Patient's baseline systolic blood pressure is in the 60s-70s, and it is unclear if this is an accurate measurement. The patient is being treated symptomatically with Dilaudid and Ativan.
3. Hypokalemia: Patient is on dialysis and kayexelate, and potassium levels need to be repleted as needed.
4. ESRD: Patient is on dialysis MWF, and the next scheduled dialysis is on [**1-11**].
5. Diabetes: Patient is on QID FS and ISS if needed.
6. Lymphoma: Patient is in the middle of a cycle of oncovine, bendamustine, and decadron, and rituximab was held off due to episode of chest pain. The patient's oncology team needs to be consulted regarding further chemotherapy in the setting of transfer to the ICU.
7. Pneumonia: CXR shows worsening opacity in the retrocardiac portion of the left lower lobe and part of the adjacent lingula, which could be due to evolving pneumonia.

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue to manage chest pain symptomatically with Dilaudid and Ativan.
* Attempt to initiate beta-blocker if BP tolerates.
* Transfuse for Hct <30.
* Trend CE and consider anticoagulation.
* Continue aspirin, clopidogrel, and atorvastatin.
* Discuss with patient, cardiologist, and other providers about the utility of placing an arterial line.
* Monitor K, phos, LDH, and uric acid Q12 (or Q8 if labs continue to be unconcerning).
* Continue decadron 20 mg IV x 5 days and allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD.
* Acetaminophen and diphenhydramine prior to rituximab.
* Confirm with renal team regarding dialysis schedule.

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and his disposition is to remain in the ICU for now.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF, moderate to severe AS, CAD, recent NSTEMI, and B-cell lymphoma. He is currently in the ICU for recurrent episodes of chest pain.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.3°C (97.4°F)
* Heart rate: 101 bpm (94-120 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 49/31 mmHg (34/22-93/49 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 17 breaths per minute (0-31 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 90%
* SpO2: 90%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 3.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 7.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 65
* Creatinine: 6.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.18 ng/mL
* Glucose: 151 mg/dL
* Calcium: 6.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.6 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 7.0 mg/dL
* Uric acid: 8.6 mg/dL

The patient's CXR shows worsening opacity involving the retrocardiac portion of the left lower lobe and part of the adjacent lingula, which could be due to evolving pneumonia. Mild interstitial edema has slightly worsened in the interval. Cardiomediastinal contours appear unchanged. New small pleural effusions, left greater than right.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Chest pain: The patient's chest pain is consistent with ischemia, but it is difficult to treat due to his AS and CAD. He is being treated symptomatically with Dilaudid and Ativan.
* Hypoxia: The patient's oxygen requirement has increased slightly since ICU transfer, but his respiratory symptoms and CXR have not worsened. He will be monitored closely.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has improved after HD, and he is stable in the 90s.
* Follicular lymphoma: The patient is in the middle of a cycle of chemotherapy and is scheduled to receive rituximab. However, this has been held off due to his episode of chest pain. He will be monitored closely.
* Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium levels will be repleted as needed.
* ESRD: The patient is on dialysis three times a week and will need to confirm his next scheduled dialysis date.
* Diabetes: The patient's blood sugar will be monitored and managed with insulin sliding scale.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Pneumonia: The patient's worsening opacity on CXR could indicate pneumonia, which could worsen his respiratory symptoms and increase his risk of sepsis.
* Ischemia: The patient's chest pain could indicate ischemia, which could lead to a myocardial infarction or other cardiac complications.
* Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to his lymphoma and chemotherapy could increase his risk of infection, which could be life-threatening.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could worsen his perfusion and increase his risk of organ damage.
* Hypokalemia: The patient's hypokalemia could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
* ESRD: The patient's ESRD could worsen his kidney function and increase his risk of complications, such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.

It is essential to monitor the patient closely and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent these complications and improve his overall outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's health status remains unstable. Notable findings include:

1. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is 49/31 mmHg, indicating hypotension, which may be a sign of septic shock or cardiac dysfunction.
2. Respiratory compromise: The patient's oxygen saturation is 90%, and the arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate respiratory acidosis (pH 7.28). This may indicate worsening respiratory failure.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's heart rate is 101 bpm, and the electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia. The cardiac examination reveals normal S1 and S2 sounds, but the patient's blood pressure is low.
4. Renal compromise: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing (6.5-5.3 mg/dL), indicating acute kidney injury (AKI).
5. Metabolic instability: The patient's glucose levels are fluctuating (30-188 mg/dL), and the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level is elevated (1556 IU/L), which may indicate tissue hypoxia.
6. Infectious complications: The patient has a worsening opacity in the left lower lobe on chest X-ray (CXR), which may be indicative of evolving pneumonia.

ll need to confirm with renal.

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a history of ESRD on HD, chronic sCHF, moderate to severe AS, CAD, and B-cell lymphoma. He was admitted to the ICU with recurrent episodes of chest pain, which is consistent with ischemia but difficult to treat due to his AS. He has been treated symptomatically with Dilaudid and Ativan. His current vital signs include a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 101 bpm, blood pressure of 49/31 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 90%. He has a white blood cell count of 3.4 K/uL and a hemoglobin level of 7.5 g/dL. His chest X-ray shows worsening opacity in the retrocardiac portion of the left lower lobe, which could be due to evolving pneumonia.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including infusions of Ranitidine, Lorazepam, and Hydromorphone, as well as oral medications such as aspirin, clopidogrel, and atorvastatin. He is also receiving chemotherapy for his lymphoma and has been on dialysis three times a week.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's chest X-ray shows worsening opacity in the retrocardiac portion of the left lower lobe, which could be due to evolving pneumonia. This could lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and other complications.
2. Ischemia: The patient's chest pain is consistent with ischemia, which could lead to myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, and other cardiac complications.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which could lead to decreased perfusion, organ damage, and other complications.
4. Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium level is low, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
5. Infection: The patient's immune system is compromised due to his lymphoma and chemotherapy, which could lead to infections such as sepsis, pneumonia, and other complications.
6. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and dialysis dependence increase his risk of developing acute kidney injury, which could lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and other complications.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of CAD, AS, and recent NSTEMI increase his risk of developing cardiovascular complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and myocardial infarction.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic lung disease and pneumonia increase his risk of developing respiratory failure, which could lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and other complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient, a 73-year-old male with significant CAD and B-cell lymphoma, was admitted to the ICU with chest pain, tachycardia, and hypotension. The patient has a history of chronic renal failure and is currently undergoing hemodialysis. He is also taking medications for coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and B-cell lymphoma.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Acute Coronary Syndrome:** The patient's chest pain and elevated troponin levels suggest the possibility of acute coronary syndrome, which could lead to further cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
2. **Chronic Renal Failure:** The patient's persistent chronic renal failure could lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and uremia.
3. **Congestive Heart Failure:** The patient's history of congestive heart failure and current hypotension could lead to further decompensation, resulting in pulmonary edema, cardiac arrest, or death.
4. **B-Cell Lymphoma:** The patient's B-cell lymphoma could progress, leading to further complications, such as bleeding, infections, or organ dysfunction.
5. **Fluid Overload:** The patient's fluid overload, as indicated by his blood pressure and fluid balance data, could lead to further complications, such as pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, or electrolyte imbalances.
6. **Infections:** The patient's indwelling lines and catheters could increase the risk of infections, such as catheter-related bloodstream infections or ventilator-associated pneumonia.
7. **Glycemic Control:** The patient's glycemic control could be compromised, leading to hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia, which could have further complications, such as infections, organ dysfunction, or cardiac complications.

**Plan:**

Based on the patient's condition, the plan should focus on managing his chest pain, chronic renal failure, congestive heart failure, and B-cell lymphoma. The patient should be closely monitored for any signs of cardiac complications, and his medications should be adjusted accordingly. The patient's fluid balance should be closely monitored to prevent fluid overload, and his glycemic control should be maintained through regular insulin sliding scale.

   Assessment and Plan
   73 yoM with multiple medical problems including lymphoma, ESRD, CAD,
   CHF and AS transferred from [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] to CCU in anticipation of cardiac cath
   in setting of unstable angina.
   # CORONARIES: Patinet's symptoms, ECG changes and probably troponin
   leak are all suggestive of ongoing coronary ischemia. Acute treatment
   of pain is unfortuantely limited by patient's low blood pressure and
   aortic stenosis. He is planned to undergo cardiac catheterization
   tomorrow as above.
   -continue metoprolol
   -continue digoxin for rate and symptom control
   -continue ASA, clopidogrel for now with understanding that patient's
   thrombocytopenia likely increases bleeding risk
   -continue lisinopril for BP control
   -continue IV dilaudid PRN for pain control as BP tolerates
   -could consider initiation of an antianginal such as ranolizine, which
   may have less preload effect than nitrates, although this would still
   need to be done cautiously given baseline low blood pressures and ESRD
   # RHYTHM: Currently in AF. Rate control appears suboptimal, and may be
   contributing to chest pain. Would consider further uptitration of beta
   blocker as patient has appeared to tolerate well thus far. On dual
   antiplatelet therapy; not anticoagulated given underlying hematologic
   malignancy.
   # PUMP: Overall appears fairly euvolemic. Patient has had intermittent
   hypotension throughout his course, likely related to poor forward flow
   from CHF/AS. Continue digoxin and low-dose beta blocker as tolerated.
   Would consider small fluid boluses as needed for hypotension, although
   patient has not been symptomatic with this thus far.
   # hypoxia: Exact etiology unclear; potentially multifactorial in
   setting of possible atelectasis, small pleural effusions. 02
   requirement has increased slightly since ICU transfer (4 to 6L) Patient
   remains without any pulmonary symptoms or evidence of infection; should
   these develop, low threshold to start antibiotics given increasing
   consolidation on chest film.
   - repeat CXR tomorrow
   - consider vanco/Zosyn/levofloxacin if CXR or clinical status worsens
   # Follicular lymphoma: Patient is in middle of cycle of oncovine,
   bendamustine, and decadron administered. Originally scheduled to
   receive rituximab on [**2151-1-9**], but held off due to episode of chest
   pain on the floor.
   -appreciate ongoing oncology input
   -continue close monitoring of K, phos, LDH, uric acid Q12
   -dexamethasone 20 mg IV x 5 days started [**1-7**], last day tomorrow
   -allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD
   # ESRD: On dialysis MWF. Last dialysis today. Appreciate renal input.
   Continue Nephrocape, calcium acetate.
   # Diabetes: Fair control based on lab sugars. QID FS. ISS.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male with multiple medical problems, including lymphoma, ESRD, CAD, CHF, and AS. He was transferred to the ICU from the CCU in anticipation of cardiac catheterization due to unstable angina.

The patient's current condition is stable, with no acute events overnight. He is receiving various medications, including anticoagulants, antiplatelet agents, beta blockers, and pain management medications.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition and treatment include:

1. Coronary ischemia: The patient's symptoms, ECG changes, and troponin leak suggest ongoing coronary ischemia. This may lead to further cardiac events, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
2. Bleeding risk: The patient's thrombocytopenia increases the risk of bleeding complications, particularly with the use of antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants.
3. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure may worsen due to the use of beta blockers and other medications, leading to decreased cardiac output and organ perfusion.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's requirement for increased oxygen therapy and potential atelectasis or small pleural effusions may lead to respiratory failure.
5. Infection: The patient's increased consolidation on chest film and potential pulmonary symptoms may indicate the development of a pulmonary infection, which could worsen his condition.
6. Lymphoma progression: The patient's ongoing chemotherapy and potential rituximab treatment may not effectively control his lymphoma, leading to disease progression and worsening symptoms.
7. ESRD complications: The patient's ESRD may lead to complications such as electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, or infections, which could worsen his overall condition.
8. Diabetes management: The patient's fair control of his diabetes may lead to complications such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia, which could worsen his overall condition.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   73 yoM with multiple medical problems including lymphoma, ESRD, CAD,
   CHF and AS transferred from [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] to CCU in anticipation of cardiac cath
   in setting of unstable angina.
   # CORONARIES: Patinet's symptoms, ECG changes and probably troponin
   leak are all suggestive of ongoing coronary ischemia. Acute treatment
   of pain is unfortuantely limited by patient's low blood pressure and
   aortic stenosis. He is planned to undergo cardiac catheterization
   tomorrow as above.
   -continue metoprolol
   -continue digoxin for rate and symptom control
   -continue ASA, clopidogrel for now with understanding that patient's
   thrombocytopenia likely increases bleeding risk
   -continue lisinopril for BP control
   -continue IV dilaudid PRN for pain control as BP tolerates
   -could consider initiation of an antianginal such as ranolizine, which
   may have less preload effect than nitrates, although this would still
   need to be done cautiously given baseline low blood pressures and ESRD
   # RHYTHM: Currently in AF. Rate control appears suboptimal, and may be
   contributing to chest pain. Would consider further uptitration of beta
   blocker as patient has appeared to tolerate well thus far. On dual
   antiplatelet therapy; not anticoagulated given underlying hematologic
   malignancy.
   # PUMP: Overall appears fairly euvolemic. Patient has had intermittent
   hypotension throughout his course, likely related to poor forward flow
   from CHF/AS. Continue digoxin and low-dose beta blocker as tolerated.
   Would consider small fluid boluses as needed for hypotension, although
   patient has not been symptomatic with this thus far.
   # hypoxia: Exact etiology unclear; potentially multifactorial in
   setting of possible atelectasis, small pleural effusions. 02
   requirement has increased slightly since ICU transfer (4 to 6L) Patient
   remains without any pulmonary symptoms or evidence of infection; should
   these develop, low threshold to start antibiotics given increasing
   consolidation on chest film.
   - repeat CXR tomorrow
   - consider vanco/Zosyn/levofloxacin if CXR or clinical status worsens
   # Follicular lymphoma: Patient is in middle of cycle of oncovine,
   bendamustine, and decadron administered. Originally scheduled to
   receive rituximab on [**2151-1-9**], but held off due to episode of chest
   pain on the floor.
   -appreciate ongoing oncology input
   -continue close monitoring of K, phos, LDH, uric acid Q12
   -dexamethasone 20 mg IV x 5 days started [**1-7**], last day tomorrow
   -allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD
   # ESRD: On dialysis MWF. Last dialysis today. Appreciate renal input.
   Continue Nephrocape, calcium acetate.
   # Diabetes: Fair control based on lab sugars. QID FS. ISS.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male with multiple medical problems, including lymphoma, End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD), Coronary Artery Disease (CAD), Congestive Heart Failure (CHF), and Aortic Stenosis (AS). He was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to unstable angina and is planned for cardiac catheterization tomorrow.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C (98.5°F), heart rate of 96 beats per minute (bpm), and blood pressure of 79/44 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 99%.

The patient's physical examination reveals a well-appearing adult male with no acute distress. He has bibasilar rales on chest examination and a mild systolic murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border (LUSB). His abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

Laboratory results show:

* White Blood Cell Count (WBC): 3.4-3.0 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.4-7.1 g/dL
* Platelet Count (Plt): 65-40 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 6.5-4.0 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.18-0.30 ng/mL
* Glucose: 30-184 mg/dL
* Other lab results are within normal limits.

The patient's medical conditions and medications are as follows:

* Lymphoma: Patient is in the middle of a cycle of oncovine, bendamustine, and decadron.
* ESRD: Patient is on dialysis three times a week.
* CAD: Patient has a history of coronary artery disease.
* CHF: Patient has a history of congestive heart failure.
* AS: Patient has aortic stenosis.
* Medications: Metoprolol, digoxin, aspirin, clopidogrel, lisinopril, ranitidine, allopurinol, dexamethasone, and oxycodone.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Coronary ischemia: The patient's symptoms, ECG changes, and troponin leak suggest ongoing coronary ischemia.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he has had intermittent hypotension throughout his course.
3. Chest pain: The patient's chest pain may be related to coronary ischemia, CHF, or AS.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's rhythm is currently in atrial fibrillation, and his rate control appears suboptimal.
5. Hypoxia: The patient's oxygen requirement has increased slightly since ICU transfer, and his exact etiology is unclear.
6. Pneumonia: The patient has small pleural effusions, and his oxygen requirement has increased, which may indicate pneumonia.
7. Bleeding risk: The patient's thrombocytopenia increases his bleeding risk, particularly with the use of antiplatelet agents.
8. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his immunocompromised state and presence of central lines.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue metoprolol, digoxin, and aspirin for rate and symptom control.
2. Continue lisinopril for blood pressure control.
3. Continue IV dilaudid PRN for pain control as blood pressure tolerates.
4. Consider initiation of an antianginal medication such as ranolizine, which may have less preload effect than nitrates.
5. Uptitrate beta blocker as tolerated to control atrial fibrillation.
6. Continue digoxin and low-dose beta blocker as tolerated for rate control.
7. Repeat CXR tomorrow and consider vanco/Zosyn/levofloxacin if CXR or clinical status worsens.
8. Continue close monitoring of K, phos, LDH, and uric acid levels.
9. Continue dexamethasone 20 mg IV x 5 days started on [**1-7**], last day tomorrow.
10. Continue allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD.
11. Continue Nephrocape and calcium acetate.
12. Appreciate ongoing oncology input and close monitoring of the patient's condition.

   # CORONARIES: Patinet's symptoms, ECG changes and probably troponin

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male with multiple medical problems, including lymphoma, end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and aortic stenosis (AS). He was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to unstable angina and is awaiting cardiac catheterization.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T max 36.9°C (98.5°F), T current 36.9°C (98.5°F), heart rate 96 bpm, blood pressure 79/44 mmHg, respiratory rate 31 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 99%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's cardiac output is likely impaired due to CHF and AS, which may contribute to his hypotension.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 480 mL of fluids over the past 24 hours, with a net fluid loss of 1320 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and has an arterial blood gas (ABG) result of pH 7.31, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) 31 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) 102 mmHg.
* Laboratory results: The patient's complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell count of 3.4 K/uL, platelet count of 65 K/uL, and hemoglobin level of 8.4 g/dL. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 184 mg/dL, creatinine level is 6.5 mg/dL, and troponin-T level is 0.30 ng/mL.

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Ongoing coronary ischemia, which may require further management and treatment.
* Suboptimal rate control, which may contribute to chest pain and potentially worsen the patient's condition.
* Hypotension, which may be related to poor forward flow from CHF/AS and may require further management and treatment.
* Hypoxia, which may be multifactorial and potentially related to atelectasis, small pleural effusions, or other factors.
* Lymphoma, which may require ongoing oncology input and close monitoring of laboratory results.
* ESRD, which requires ongoing dialysis and management.
* Diabetes, which appears to be under fair control.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue metoprolol, digoxin, and lisinopril as previously ordered.
* Continue IV dilaudid as needed for pain control, with caution due to the patient's low blood pressure and ESRD.
* Consider initiation of an antianginal medication such as ranolizine, although this would need to be done cautiously given the patient's baseline low blood pressures and ESRD.
* Continue digoxin and low-dose beta blocker as tolerated, with consideration of small fluid boluses as needed for hypotension.
* Repeat CXR tomorrow and consider vanco/Zosyn/levofloxacin if CXR or clinical status worsens.
* Continue close monitoring of K, phos, LDH, and uric acid levels Q12.
* Dexamethasone 20 mg IV x 5 days started yesterday, with the last day tomorrow.
* Allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD.
* Continue Nephrocape and calcium acetate.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his multiple medical conditions, with a focus on optimizing his cardiac output, managing his hypotension, and preventing complications such as hypoxia and infection.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 73-year-old male with multiple medical problems, including lymphoma, end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and aortic stenosis (AS). He was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization due to unstable angina. The patient's symptoms, ECG changes, and troponin leak suggest ongoing coronary ischemia. He is currently receiving treatment for pain, rhythm control, and pump failure. The patient's electrolyte and laboratory values are being closely monitored.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:**
	* Ongoing coronary ischemia may lead to further cardiac events, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
	* The patient's aortic stenosis may worsen with further cardiac stress.
	* The patient's CHF may progress, leading to increased fluid accumulation and worsening respiratory status.
2. **Respiratory Complications:**
	* The patient's hypoxia may worsen due to atelectasis, small pleural effusions, or underlying lung disease.
	* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections may develop, particularly with increased consolidation on chest film.
3. **Renal Complications:**
	* The patient's ESRD may worsen with further fluid accumulation or electrolyte imbalances.
	* The patient's dialysis schedule may need to be adjusted to manage fluid overload or electrolyte imbalances.
4. **Hematological Complications:**
	* The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase bleeding risk with further antiplatelet therapy or anticoagulation.
	* The patient's underlying hematologic malignancy may progress, leading to worsening anemia, bleeding, or infection.
5. **Infectious Complications:**
	* The patient may develop pneumonia, sepsis, or other infections, particularly with increased consolidation on chest film or underlying immunocompromise.
6. **Metabolic Complications:**
	* The patient's diabetes may worsen with further hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
	* The patient's electrolyte imbalances may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or other metabolic complications.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's cardiac, respiratory, renal, and hematological status.
2. Adjust antiplatelet and anticoagulation therapy as necessary to balance bleeding risk and thrombotic risk.
3. Consider further uptitration of beta blockers for rate control and symptom management.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte and laboratory values closely, adjusting therapy as necessary to manage electrolyte imbalances and prevent further cardiac complications.
5. Repeat chest X-ray and consider antibiotics if the patient's respiratory status worsens or consolidation on chest film increases.
6. Continue close communication with the patient's oncology team to manage his underlying hematologic malignancy and adjust therapy as necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   73 yoM with multiple medical problems including lymphoma, ESRD, CAD,
   CHF and AS transferred from [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] to CCU in anticipation of cardiac cath
   in setting of unstable angina.
   # CORONARIES: Patinet's symptoms, ECG changes and probably troponin
   leak are all suggestive of ongoing coronary ischemia. Acute treatment
   of pain is unfortuantely limited by patient's low blood pressure and
   aortic stenosis. He is planned to undergo cardiac catheterization today
   as above.
   -continue metoprolol as tolerated by BP
   -continue digoxin for rate and symptom control
   -continue ASA, clopidogrel for now with understanding that patient's
   thrombocytopenia likely increases bleeding risk
   -hold lisinopril in setting of low BP
   -continue IV dilaudid PRN for pain control as BP tolerates
   -could consider initiation of an antianginal such as ranolizine, which
   may have less preload effect than nitrates, although this would still
   need to be done cautiously given baseline low blood pressures and ESRD
   # RHYTHM: Currently in NSR, although admitted in afib. Rate control
   appears suboptimal, and may be contributing to chest pain. Would
   consider further uptitration of beta blocker as patient has appeared to
   tolerate well thus far. On dual antiplatelet therapy; not
   anticoagulated given underlying hematologic malignancy.
   # PUMP: Overall appears fairly euvolemic to mildly hypervolemic with
   crackles on exam. Patient has had intermittent hypotension throughout
   his course, likely related to poor forward flow from CHF/AS.
   - continue digoxin and low-dose beta blocker as tolerated
   - would consider small fluid boluses as needed for hypotension,
   although patient has not been symptomatic with this thus far
   - cont dialysis MWF for overall fluid management
   # hypoxia: Exact etiology unclear; potentially multifactorial in
   setting of possible atelectasis, small pleural effusions. 02
   requirement has increased slightly since ICU transfer (4 to 6L) Patient
   remains without any pulmonary symptoms or evidence of infection; should
   these develop, low threshold to start antibiotics given increasing
   consolidation on chest film.
   - repeat CXR tomorrow
   - low threshold to consider vanco/Zosyn/levofloxacin if CXR or clinical
   status worsens
   # Follicular lymphoma: Patient is in middle of cycle of oncovine,
   bendamustine, and decadron administered. Originally scheduled to
   receive rituximab on [**2151-1-9**], but held off due to episode of chest
   pain on the floor.
   -appreciate ongoing oncology input
   -continue close monitoring of K, phos, LDH, uric acid Q12
   -dexamethasone 20 mg IV x 5 days started [**1-7**], last day today
   -allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD
   # ESRD: On dialysis MWF. Last dialysis today. Appreciate renal input.
   Continue Nephrocape, calcium acetate.
   # Diabetes: Fair control based on lab sugars. QID FS. ISS.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO/ replete lytes prn
   Lines:
   Indwelling Port (PortaCath) - [**2151-1-8**] 07:30 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2151-1-8**] 07:30 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin SC
   Stress ulcer:  ranitidine
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: full
   Disposition: CCU pending cardiac cath and stabilization of chest
   discomfort

Based on the patient's daily progress note, I summarize the following:

The patient, a 73-year-old male, is a complex case with multiple medical problems, including lymphoma, End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD), Coronary Artery Disease (CAD), Congestive Heart Failure (CHF), and Aortic Stenosis (AS). He was transferred to the Cardiovascular Intensive Care Unit (CCU) for further management of unstable angina.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 36.9°C (98.5°F), Heart Rate 96 bpm, Blood Pressure 79/44 mmHg, Respiratory Rate 31 breaths per minute, Oxygen Saturation 99%.
* Physical examination: The patient appears well, with bibasilar rales and a mildly tachycardic heart rate. A harsh systolic murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border.
* Lab results: The patient has thrombocytopenia, anemia, and elevated troponin levels, indicating ongoing coronary ischemia.

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Continue metoprolol as tolerated by blood pressure.
* Continue digoxin for rate and symptom control.
* Hold lisinopril due to low blood pressure.
* Continue IV dilaudid PRN for pain control.
* Consider initiation of an antianginal medication, such as ranolizine, cautiously given the patient's baseline low blood pressures and ESRD.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Ongoing coronary ischemia, which can lead to recurrent chest pain, arrhythmias, and even myocardial infarction.
2. Thrombocytopenia, which can increase the risk of bleeding complications.
3. Anemia, which can exacerbate cardiovascular symptoms.
4. Hypoxia, which can be caused by atelectasis, small pleural effusions, or other factors, and can lead to respiratory failure.
5. Infection, which can develop in the setting of compromised immune function and underlying medical conditions.
6. Bleeding complications, which can occur due to thrombocytopenia and anticoagulation therapy.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias, which can be caused by digoxin toxicity or other factors.
8. Kidney injury, which can occur due to hypoperfusion or other factors in the setting of ESRD.

Based on the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, close monitoring and multidisciplinary care are necessary to manage his condition and prevent adverse outcomes.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Coronary Ischemia: The patient's symptoms, ECG changes, and troponin leak suggest ongoing coronary ischemia. The patient's low blood pressure and aortic stenosis limit the acute treatment of pain.
2. Hypotension: The patient's intermittent hypotension is likely related to poor forward flow from CHF/AS. Close monitoring of blood pressure and fluid management is essential.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's increased oxygen requirement and bibasilar consolidation on CXR suggest the possibility of respiratory failure. Close monitoring of oxygen saturation and respiratory status is necessary.
4. Infection: The patient's small pleural effusions and increasing consolidation on CXR may indicate the development of infection. A low threshold for starting antibiotics is necessary if symptoms or CXR findings worsen.
5. Hematologic Complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia increases the risk of bleeding, and the patient is already on dual antiplatelet therapy. Close monitoring of platelet counts and bleeding risk is essential.
6. Cardiac Arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and current sinus rhythm suggest a risk of cardiac arrhythmias. Close monitoring of heart rhythm and rate control is necessary.
7. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's history of ESRD and ongoing dialysis may lead to electrolyte imbalances. Close monitoring of potassium, phosphorus, and calcium levels is necessary.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of ESRD and ongoing dialysis may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as constipation or diarrhea. Close monitoring of bowel habits and stool patterns is necessary.
9. Oncologic Complications: The patient's ongoing chemotherapy and history of lymphoma may lead to oncologic complications such as bleeding or infection. Close monitoring of oncologic status and treatment is necessary.

In summary, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including coronary ischemia, hypotension, respiratory failure, infection, hematologic complications, cardiac arrhythmias, electrolyte imbalance, gastrointestinal complications, and oncologic complications. Close monitoring and management of these complications are essential to ensure the patient's safety and well-being.

   currently being weaned.  Likely has low baseline BP and has adequate
   end-organ perfusion with SBP in 70s
   - wean IABP, d/c as possible

   thrombocytopenia likely increases bleeding risk
   -hold B-blocker and lisinopril in setting of low BP
   -continue IV dilaudid PRN for pain control as BP tolerates
   -could consider initiation of an antianginal such as ranolizine, which
   may have less preload effect than nitrates, although this would still
   need to be done cautiously given baseline low blood pressures and ESRD
   # HAP: left lower lobe infiltrate on CXR, cough, new O2 requirement
   (increased slightly since [**Hospital **] transfer from 4 to 6L).  Afebrile with no

   immunocompromised status
   - trend WBC, fever curve

   # RHYTHM: Currently in NSR, although admitted in afib. Rate control
   appears suboptimal, and may be contributing to chest pain. On dual

   malignancy.
   - hold b-blocker in light of cardiogenic shock
   # PUMP: Overall appears fairly euvolemic to mildly hypervolemic with

   his course, likely related to poor forward flow from CHF/AS.
   - continue digoxin and low-dose beta blocker as tolerated
   - would consider small fluid boluses as needed for hypotension,
   although patient has not been symptomatic with this thus far
   - cont dialysis MWF for overall fluid management
   # Follicular lymphoma: Patient is in middle of cycle of oncovine,

   -appreciate ongoing oncology input

   Assessment and Plan
   73 yoM with multiple medical problems including lymphoma, ESRD, CAD,
   CHF and AS transferred from [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] to CCU in anticipation of cardiac cath
   in setting of unstable angina.
   # Hypotension: most consistent with cardiogenic shock likely
   precipitated by small ischemic event although CE flat.  No evidence of
   mechanical complication- i.e. acute valvular pathology, septal defect,
   etc; tamponade; PE.  Currently requiring pressors and IABP, settings
   currently being weaned.  Likely has low baseline BP and has adequate
   end-organ perfusion with SBP in 70s
   - wean IABP, d/c as possible
   - wean phenylephrine and change to levophed as needed, keeping MAP > 55
   - monitor for cx of IABP i.e. limb ischemia, cholesterol emboli, CVA,
   etc
   - cont to cycle CE
   # CORONARIES: s/p cath yest revealing triple vessel dx with BMS to mid
   and ostial LAD.  Tolerated procedure well with no cx.  No further
   recurrence of anginal sx.
   -cycle CE
   -continue digoxin for rate and symptom control
   -continue ASA, clopidogrel for now with understanding that patient's
   thrombocytopenia likely increases bleeding risk
   -hold B-blocker and lisinopril in setting of low BP
   -continue IV dilaudid PRN for pain control as BP tolerates
   -could consider initiation of an antianginal such as ranolizine, which
   may have less preload effect than nitrates, although this would still
   need to be done cautiously given baseline low blood pressures and ESRD
   # HAP: left lower lobe infiltrate on CXR, cough, new O2 requirement
   (increased slightly since [**Hospital **] transfer from 4 to 6L).  Afebrile with no
   leukocytosis although pt at high risk of infection with
   immunocompromised status
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - send repeat sputum cx
   - f/u final read CXR
   - start cefepime/ vancomycin for 8 day course
   # RHYTHM: Currently in NSR, although admitted in afib. Rate control
   appears suboptimal, and may be contributing to chest pain. On dual
   antiplatelet therapy; not anticoagulated given underlying hematologic
   malignancy.
   - hold b-blocker in light of cardiogenic shock
   # PUMP: Overall appears fairly euvolemic to mildly hypervolemic with
   crackles on exam. Patient has had intermittent hypotension throughout
   his course, likely related to poor forward flow from CHF/AS.
   - continue digoxin and low-dose beta blocker as tolerated
   - would consider small fluid boluses as needed for hypotension,
   although patient has not been symptomatic with this thus far
   - cont dialysis MWF for overall fluid management
   # Follicular lymphoma: Patient is in middle of cycle of oncovine,
   bendamustine, and decadron administered. Originally scheduled to
   receive rituximab on [**2151-1-9**], but held off due to episode of chest
   pain on the floor.
   -appreciate ongoing oncology input
   -continue close monitoring of K, phos, LDH, uric acid Q12
   -allopurinol 100 mg PO QOD
   # ESRD: On dialysis MWF.
   - dialysis today
   - Appreciate renal input
   - Continue Nephrocape, calcium acetate.
   # Diabetes: Fair control based on lab sugars. QID FS. ISS.
